description.text: This is a co-axial air assist for the LaserSaur laser cutter that I turned from some 6061 Aluminum round stock.

I've provieded the original Solidworks files and .step.  The air inlet connector is from McMaster Carr for 1/4" tube, but any quick-connect with 10-32 threads will work.  The coiled 1/4" tubing is also from McMaster.  It's lashed to the back rail of the 'saur with zip-ties and run out of the enclosure with 1/4" Swagelok bulkhead fittings and eventually meets up with an air compressor and regulator.
The airflow requirements are pretty minimal, so 1/8" tubing could also be used and would bend easier.  A 1/8 - 1/4" adapter would be needed then to use the coiled tubing.

description.text:

The file uploaded is a dxf the is suited for laser cutting. The borders are shared to minimize waste and decrease laser on time.

title: Extension Cable Connector {Home Safety and neatly}

description.text:
I got tired of taped up cable joints. they become tacky and the cables short out.

I fill the mould with marine grade silicone after joining the wires together.
This helps with insulation, and provides some adhesive strength to the joint.

You can also use hot glue from a glue gun, probably going to work better.

Use a M4 bolt, between 15mm and 20mm long to fasten the 2 sides together.
If you can get plastic bolts that is even better, for added safety.

comments.text: Yikes, if middle wire is live and touching the screw (like the picture) you might be in for a surprise..
comments.author: dvan

comments.text: Be careful with this.  Your home owner's insurance probably won't cover a home made non UL listed mains hack.
comments.author: anode505

comments.text: Agree with the other comment. This isn't a great way to attach two wires. There's not a lot of mechanical strength and I question the safety.
comments.author: micahstevens

comments.text: If those wires are not soldered together you have your self a huge firehazard just waiting to happen. There is a reason that wires should be either fastend with screws, clamps or soldering. The reason is the alternating current that can start arcing in joints that are loose, like the ones in your picture.  No amount of silicone, adhesive or other very flammable material can help that. Solder, screw or clamp wires. Do not twist them together...

Support pour camera raspberry se fixant dans un coin du plateau d'origine de la Discovery200 de Dagoma.

L'utilisation de la rallonge (ou plusieurs) évite que le boitier de la camera ne rentre en contact avec une pièce de l'imprimante.

Le support peut être sécurisé avec la vis ( a recouper en longueur). Cette pièce reste optionnelle, en cas de problème ou choc, le support glissera du plateau facilement.

Camera holder for a raspicam and Dagoma Discovery 200. Just slide the holder on the printing plate and bolt on the camera case.

Distance and angle between the camera and the printing plate can be adjusted by adding parts "Cam_Holder_2"

The holder can be secured with a bolt (lenght has to be adapted). This part is optionnal. The holder can slide gently if the case is in contact with a moving part during the print...

title: Alot of plastic
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
If you like my work alot, I hope you'll consider supporting me on Pateron: https://www.patreon.com/3DPrintingProfessor Subscribe to me on YouTube: https://www.youtube.com/user/mrjoesays The alot is a creation of Allie Brosh. If you're unfamiliar with the alot here's her explination:
http://hyperboleandahalf.blogspot.com/2010/04/alot-is-better-than-you-at-everything.html The 3D Artist contest asked "what monster would you like to have in your pocket." I would like to have alot in my pocket. Then take it out, put it on my noggin, and tell everyone I have alot on my mind. You can print alot with your 3D printer. You can give alot to your friends. Alot! EDIT: V2 features more hurp, more durp, and most importantly more a visible tooth on a better lip. Recomend using V2.

comments.text: Is it bad that this has become my calibration print? very curvy
comments.author: WesBur13

comments.text: So you calibrate... alot?
comments.author: WesBur13

comments.text: TRIGGERED
comments.author: cymon

comments.text: This turned out amazing! Thanks so much for this model!
comments.author: Captain_Parsimony

comments.text: I'm having problems printing this without100% infil.  It seems no matter what I specify for the infill, I end up with a form that's 100% filled in.  This is living up to it's name: ALOT of plastic!
comments.author: txoof

comments.text: Hey txoof,
comments.author: txoof

comments.text: I made this model hoping to win a 3D printer. I didn't. So I have no idea how to help you. But I've started a thread on the thingiverse google group so hopefully someone will be able to help you here:
comments.author: txoof

comments.text: I eventually got this to print properly.  There was something funky in my SF settings.  Starting from scratch with SF is sometimes the best option.
comments.author: cymon

comments.text: I scaled it in replicatorg and printed it at 200% size and the details are much clearer! You could say that a bigger Alot is alot better. I can really recommend you to try it. (No pic due to a fatal filament roll snag mid print.)
comments.author: Jaknil

comments.text: So what you're saying is "alot bigger is alot better."
comments.author: Jaknil

comments.text: Here you go! Each paw measures 25 mm or 1 inch if you are like that. My phone really doesn't like the "Fire Truck Red" PLA. I'll give it another go when I get more plastic and finish the parts for a Prusa Mendel for a friend. I am thinking of going full out and making it 210mm long   8-)
comments.author: cymon

comments.text: That's so cool. Did the rest of it print? Is the fail only in that middle part or did you cancel it before it got to the eyeballs and tooth?
comments.author: Jaknil

comments.text: The top broke loose when it was starting work on the head. The garbled 5 mm in the middle gave way. I spared you the ghastly sight of its headless neck, not a pretty sight at all. But the best thing about having a printer is that I can just print a new one. So I'll do just that but it seems it will have to be in transparent PLA, I really need to order some more! Like I said below, we need to get you one, and I don't mind making one for you if it comes to that.
comments.author: cymon

comments.text: oh, this is too much awesome! i can't wait to go home and print this alot.
comments.author: origamimavin

comments.text: Have you thought about using Shapeways? I'm tempted to try and make alot of ceramic for $16.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: As long as you don't make it public and try to sell copies I say go for it.
comments.author: Guest

comments.text: awesome, I love waking up and finding something I just need to have RIGHT NOW :)
comments.author: jamesglanville

comments.text: I'm going to print this Alot. :)
comments.author: cyclone

comments.text: I sure hope you got Ms Brosh's permission, or the copyright monster might bite you alot.
comments.author: MtDon

comments.text: Legally I think it may be arguable either way, but I'll bet she'd approve. I'll send her an email in fact.
comments.author: MtDon

comments.text: From her FAQ:
comments.author: cymon

comments.text: I checked her page and sadly it's quite clear on "No derivatives". The link is on the right hand side, under Copyright.
comments.author: MtDon

comments.text: between you and Andreas I'm going to have quite a collection or monsters.
comments.author: Grog

comments.text: This is great.  I'll definitely print one as soon as I get a chance. :-D
comments.author: kellesabelle

comments.text: Someone seriously needs to buy you a printer. Do you have a hackerspace near you?
comments.author: pogden

comments.text: There is a Provo Utah hackerspace but it's tough for me to get to and difficult for me to afford the membership fees to. That is why I'll be entering every contest I can. Until I win one. Who knows, maybe the 3D Artist Magizine guys will agree with you this time. ;)
comments.author: pogden

comments.text: Great work! I just finished mine! I have the code primed for a 200% size version that I think is going to be alot better than the first one! Thanks for sharing, I (we) really appreciate it. We should send you alot perhaps? I would be happy to print you one but it seems a bit silly to ship it from Sweden so I am going out on a limb and calling for someone closer to Utah to send this man alot!
comments.author: cymon

comments.text: I like his expression  :-D

comments.text: I tried to hurp it but it durped.

comments.text: It's definitely more on the durp side of the force.

Customized version of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:58001 Created with Customizer! http://www.thingiverse.com/apps/customizer/run?thing_id=58001

I have a very curious cat, and this enclosure keeps his paws and nose safe. As a side benefit, the enclosure helps the printer maintain a more stable ambient temperature, and keeps dust off the printer.

This design is a remix of DrewPetitclerc's terrific 3D printer enclosure. There are a few notable changes:

  • Designed for thinner 0.093" acrylic sheets. (Note: Drew's original design used 0.25" thick sheets.) This makes the design lighter and less expensive. I purchased 18" x 24" x 0.093" OPTIX clear acrylic glass sheets from my local Home Depot, which sells them for $10.48/sheet.
  • Glue-together frame. No bolts or drilling required! I used Loctite 5 min Plastic Epoxy, which is plenty strong, and advertises that it is designed to be used on ABS and other hard plastics.
  • Edge brackets. These brackets keep the frame rigid, even with the thinner acrylic sheets.
  • 2mm hinge pins. I used K&S 2mm aluminum tubes for the pins, available from many hobby stores or your favorite online retailer for about $2 total. I haven't tried, but you might even be able to use a small length of 1.75mm filament as the hinge pin instead.

I chose to print in ABS for its durability, which is not as brittle as PLA. Also, the plastic epoxy is advertised to work well with ABS, though it may also be equally effective with PLA.

This project gave me the "opportunity" to learn about cutting acrylic sheets, with many mistakes made along the way. If you are equally inexperienced at this skill, you may wish to purchase an extra sheet for practice. Or plan on making that eventual trip back to Home Depot for a replacement sheet, as I did. The "score and snap" method never worked for me as well as it did on the many YouTube videos I watched. Even after scoring both sides several times and snapping along a hard corner, the sheet would inevitably crack at the wrong place. Eventually, I decided to use my trusty, $30 jig saw, which performed like a champ. The jig saw makes a nice, clean edge. I've listed several of my recommendations for using a jig saw, learned by yours truly the hard way. I think if you follow this, you might be able to make it through perfectly the first time. Make a practice cut, though, just to be sure!

  • Pick up the Bosch Plexiglass jig saw blade.
  • Wrap both sides of the acrylic sheet with masking tape, along the edge you intend to cut. I used two layers. This prevents the edge from shattering as you cut.
  • Place the sheet on a board, clamp it down, and cut right along the edge of the board. This prevents the sheet from vibrating, which can eventually cause it to shatter near the blade. Hold the loose end of the sheet as you cut, to prevent it from vibrating too much.
  • Use a medium speed, and cut at a steady pace. Be careful at both edges of the sheet, since this is the place where it is most likely to chip.

I've also included a mouse hole for the back of the enclosure, allowing power cables to pass through. This hole can also be cut with a jig saw.

I really liked schlem's swivel pass-through for his enclosure design (see http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:55065). You can see it in a few of my enclosure pictures. As he states in his instructions, a 1" hole saw drill bit works just fine for the hole. I used the same drill bit for the door handles.

When putting the enclosure together, I recommend paying very close attention to the orientation of the top corners and top edges before gluing in place. Note that the top sheet is recessed relative to the side sheets. Once the epoxy sets, the bond is permanent.

description.text:
Spektrum SPM4648 Antenna Mount

The receiver fits into the mount tightly and can be strapped on any quad with zipties easily. Though it was specifically optimized for my Vortex 250. The antenna holes have a 3,2mm diameter, a 3mm plastic tube fits in quite solid.

Protection

There are little edges in the antenna holes which protect your receiver antennas from being cut from the plastic tubes when they're heavily pushed in the whole whilst crashing. The antenna tubes have a 40° angle off the x-axis and are rotated 40° to the back. As a result "landing" your quad on the back bows the antennas out of range of the props.

Inspired

http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1201074

Receiver

Spektrum Quad Race Serial Receiver w/Diversity SPM4648

Releases

Version 1
  • initial release
Version 2
  • deleted obsolete surfaces in order to make thing work with Slic3r and Cura
  • reversed few surfaces to prevent render issues with other programs

Mounts for SI22G Geiger-Mueller tubes (beta, gamma detector tube) and terminals.
These are part of a cosmic ray detector project.

Tubes are shielded with aluminum plates.

The mounting trays are aligned and mounted on the plate with 1" standoffs.

No more losing your pens! This is parametric pen, which you can put a label on. Because who wouldn't want a pen with their name printed as the shape of the pen. You should be able to size it to slip over a Bic pen, or to use as a barrel of a pen kit. While this wasn't exactly derived from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:17339, it was certainly inspired by it. I built it in OpenSCAD, to make sizing and text generation easier. Updated so that the pen's face is at z=0, making it easier to print.

Download pen.scad. Aldo, download write.scad and your desired fonts from (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:16193) . I use that library to generate the text. Edit pen.scad to sed the desired dimensions. That is: d = 10; // outer diameter of pen (whatever size you like to hold) in mm
id = 8; // inner diameter, measure to fit your existing pen nib, etc.
h = 100; // height of pen, length of body
u = 2; // additional letter height beyond body of pen. // uncomment one to set font
//f="braille.dxf"; // braille
f="orbitron.dxf"; // cool modern font
//f="letters.dxf"; // the default font // text to embed in pen, don't make it longer than the pen body or things get weird
label="[email protected]"; // your name here For one color printing, set c=0, generate the STL, and print it. For two color printing, set c=1, compile, and generate an STL, then set c=2, compile, and generate the other, then merge for Dualstrusion and print. At least, I think so - I don't have the Replicator yet so I can't be certain.. If you like my name, print the STL files that I've attached as examples. There are four little cubes around the objects, used to force alignment of the two STLs for merging. They aren't a part of the pen, so you can do whatever you like to them. This is a 'work in progress' because I haven't printed it yet, but I'm practicing modeling for dualstrusion and sharing the objects in case anyone else is interested. These giles made it through ReplicatorG, so I think they'll print. I'm hoping that two color personalized pens will be a popular present for friends and family. I'll let you know in a month or so.

I noticed some layer shifting on my Up Box 3D printer a while ago. After inspection I saw one of the plastic parts that hold the back metal bar and bearings (X axis) was broken.

It was a little bit tricky to remove the old parts and get these printed ones back in but now the machine is printing great again. I hope this can help some people with fixing their machine, maybe print some as spares.

description.text:
Those teensy little microSD cards are just asking to get lost among the detritus of our lives, so having some way to carry them about in a slightly larger form factor is helpful. My Lozenge-sized holder is a bit more manageable to carry about, esp with the ring-hole.

You might remember my SD_Card_Six_plus_Three which holds six microSDs and three full sized SDs. It was itself a remix of card holder from @PhantomEbay.

But I've found myself mostly just swapping between two microSDs in my 3D printer, so a smaller design seemed attractive.

This one has two slots, nicely finished edges, and my patented (not really) tension-bump to ensure the card stays put in the slot nicely. It also has a chamfered key-ring hole, so you can attach it to a loop. PLUS with the small design, it prints on-edge very well, so the slots get better formed and need less clean-up after printing.

The label indent is handy for putting your contact info on, or indicating what the cards therein are related to. See my pic above for the deets.

NB: my print seems to hold the microSD cards nicely snug, yet still easily removable. There's a risk if your printer-result doesn't hold firmly. On a key-ring you may dislodge a card and lose it, so judge for yourself if it's safe to carry your data around like that. I like the loop just for hanging the thing up. :)

Printer:

MP Select Mini

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.1mm

Infill:

35%

Notes:

These settings were the ones I used. The raft is handy for a good hold-down while printing the item balanced on the edge. If you have really good bed-adhesion, you may be okay without the raft.

A .2mm resolution may be fine if your printer has that as a bottom end. Give it a shot, it's a very tiny piece that uses little filament.

I like a reasonably high-fill for durability though with such a thin item the shell may make that moot.

Printing on edge avoids the need for supports in tiny places which don't work so well.

title: Horten Flying Wing S.E. Fighter, Go suggestion

description.text:
I am building an RC model of the Ho 229, with about 160cm wingspan, which comes out to about a 1:10 scale.
I took the original wing profiles from the internet, made a wing, mirrored it and used a CNC mill do make a foam model half size (80cm). I took it out of the mill, and just out of spite, threw it in the air. It flew in a straight line, as if on tracks!

Now, still working on the model and on the fuse, I decided to go wild and create my own fuselage. There was a plan from the manufacturer of the Ho IX (Gothaer Waggonfabrik) to make a different airplane (a pure high altitude fighter), which caused a lot of fighting with the Horten brothers, also it was planned around a BMW engine that was not available then, and the plane was never built. This model here - the fuselage - is an Interpretation of what this plane - mostly the fuselage - would have looked like.
The wings however are original! In fact - print it big enough, and it should fly! Even just the wings, without the fuse (the wings joined in the middle). You will have to play around with the CG, though, a flying wing is a bit touchy with that.

And oh - if you print one, please post a picture, OK?

There is a newer Version available here: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2483573

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Infill:

see description

Notes:

Print the wings and the fuselage in the original position of the file as a spiral vase.
Print the nose and the tail in a conventional maner, with about 20% infill.
Use a file or sand paper to straighten all the planes where you glue on other parts, that's it.

comments.text: I was of the understanding that WIG craft worked better in a 'reverse-delta' configuration that generated a 'scoop of stagnant air' in the volume under the top surface of the wing.  This seems more of a traditional airfoil of a flying wing than something designed specifically for ground effect flight.

comments.text:
Okay, but dont hurry up! I've time for waiting!

comments.author: Bogomi67

comments.text:
You can either size/scale it down to fit your printer, or you can cut the parts into pieces. 3Dbuilder will do that for you.
If you go for scaling, scale a wing first, that's the largest part. Use that scale factor for the other parts.
A 160cm wingspan should fly if you print everything as a spiral vase, or no more than 2 outer layers and max. 5% infill.
The CG is crucial, and pitch is really twitchy. Low speed capability is marginal unless with a nose up and thrust.
Let me know how you did mate.
Cheers,
Thomas

description.text:
This is an alternate endstop for an HE3D Delta 180 (Kossel Mini). This bracket allows you to mount an optical sensor (switch) to 2020 extruded aluminum frame. This design will allow you to still adjust the endstop using the adjustment screw.

The hole spacing on the Optical Switch is 19mm on center and 3mm from the edge (bolt side).

Please feel free to share and modify if needed.

This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/fDnlTzzGrPo

Printer:

HE3D Delta 180 Duel Head

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.1

Infill:

35%

Notes:

Use supports or the mounting lugs of the optical sensor will a droopy blob. If you get that, don't fret just trim them flat use a washer to space it. (one of mine is like that now ;) )

Instalation

Mount the sensor to the endstop brackets using small screws. There are lugs on the bracket to space the sensor away far enough to clear any solder and chips on the back of the sensor.

I do not use bolts due to the space limitation. Make sure the screw does not protrude to far and trim off nay excess.

The verticals for the posts that mount on the carriage will need to be trimmed once mounted. I print them wide so it will print flat and have some structure. You can then trim the sides to fit the sensor you use properly.

When mounting the verticals post on the carriage, I used servo mounting screws they are long and have a decent bite. you can use what you prefer.

Please note the fit is snug. This allows you to only lightly tighten the 2020 screw. This makes adjusting the end stops mechanically a whole lot easier.

I print small parts and need close tolerances. I was having issues with my mechanical end stops not being consistent. I decided to use Arduino compatible Optical endstops.
I created these to allow me to mount them and still use the adjuster screw.

I used a strip of 1/4" flat brass strip screwed into the carriage instead of making a whole new carriage. This way I could adjust it as I prototyped. I also have a plan to make a 3dprinted one If you want to make the brass one, one you can get the brass strip at a hobby shop.

Inspired by a failed miniature print of my Big Thick Gyro Cube (see orange photo), I designed a gimbal based on the gyro cube components.

This can be printed without support.  
Since the only "closed" portion is the inner gimbal sphere, the three parts can be printed separately (separate files provided) instead of on a single platter.  
The "base" part needs to be printed in the orientation given (on its side) in order for the nib to print correctly.  
My (scaled to 70%) print didn't actually come out very good, and I actually broke it taking it off the platter.  But some ABS glue later, and a little warping with a heat gun, to form a tighter hold on the nibs, and it's functional.

title: Logitech Orbit/BCC 950 Alternate Mount for Monitor Stands!

description.text:
I finally got a stand for my monitor array, but my webcam was too low or not high enough to be used in any convenient location, so I got the appropriate USB extension cable and ground it down with a Dremel until it fit into the stalk of the Logitech BCC 950/Orbit webcam. I then made this mount to secure the cable with the camera atop. If you look at the picture of my desk, the base is on the left side, with the stalk going up, but the camera is on the right!

It even has a modular insert that I use to hold the tools to adjust the monitor stand! I have included a 'blank' STL that can be easily booleaned to hold the tools of your choice. Note the wrench part on mine had to be filed down to fit the wrench, so I suggest coming up with your own shape for holding wrenches. I like the location though.

Printer:

FFCreat0r

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

200 micron

Infill:

10%, 3 shells for USB insert

Notes:

There are two main parts, the part that goes on your monitor, and the part that holds the USB cable/tools.

For monitor mounts:
'MonitorMnt_UniCamV1.1.stl': This is the mount that fits on my Dell monitor (might work on others) and supports the webcam well

'MonitorMnt_UniCam.stl': This is a prototype.. 2D slice almost of the more stable one. Print this and you'll see pretty quickly if it'll fit your monitor or not.

For the cable holders:
'USBinsert.stl': is a generic USB cable insert to support the cable and that's all it does. Simple.

'USBins_tools.stl': is a variant with an extra area with various holes for putting allen wrenches, etc. into for easy but discreet access.

'USBins_blank.stl': is a blank version of the above, designed to be easily modified using software, or by printing at 100% infill and attacking with a drill and Dremel. Your imagination is the limit!

All parts designed to not need raft/supports. The above settings are the minimal recommended settings.
like this (but recommend printing as separate jobs)

description.text:
What is it:

This is a personal experimental solution...

As you can see in the photo i'm using screws to achieve the same function. But I thought I'd make a printable solution out of it if someone else likes to test it out. Without having good size screws available....

What it does:

Makes a bearing block somewhat floating / self-aligning and is meant to be used "only" on the guiding bearing block of the Y-axis, and only on the Y-axis (that single block in a triangle setup). Mainly to hopefully avoid/reduce unnessecary bindning of the bearing.

These straps are intended for use with two rubber o-rings and might force you to drill out the holes in a current bearing block to push right size o-rings through. So you might wan't to print out a new bearing block if testing this out.

When applied these straps are meant to force the block against the carriage plate but with a slight ability to rotate horizontally. This is important! You have to find the right size/thickness o-rings for this.

Optional:

Maybe add some nylon washers between the Y-carriage plate and the bearing block if it's an aluminium block to make is slide better. If using a printed PLA block it should slide just fine on the aluminium plate as is.

Have fun tinkering...

Thanks to the user tahustvedt and his nice bearings blocks (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1172838) one of which I used for illustrational purposes.

Also thanks to Dingoboy71 and Jace1969 for bringing up this whole floating bearing deal. Always fun to try out different solutions...

Duplicator i3 Ultra

No

No

100%

They came at night, landing a saucer shaped craft in the backyard, pulsating lights and all.

They forced me to make this... and then they left, dissapearing without moving, riding an antigravitational wake displacing spacetime bending the fabric of space...

:-)

description.text:
Parametric Lego Hailfire Wheel.

This is an approximation of Lego part-no 4481-1.Since I do not have the actual Lego piece available, the dimensions are an educated guess.

Following parameters can be used to vary the dimensions of the wheel:
scaleFactor = 1.0; //0.73;
Height = 3.7; // 7.8; refers to the height of the tooth in z-dir

scaleFactor 1.0 corresponds with the original Lego part no. A scaleFactor of 0.73 makes it possible to print the wheel on my 3D printer.

Remark:

  • the wheel can be printed without use of support structures.

The Hailfire Wheels in action:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=g9kQq8xZtlI

A couple of variations on the original...

  1. Mounting lugs, to attach to the 2020 extrusion bottom rail of a Zonestar D810 delta printer. Attach with M3x25mm screws nd M3 boat nuts
  2. Opened up the viewing angles to the LED
  3. Added labels underneath each button (need to print on a good flat bed for these to be legible)
  4. Added labels on the top of each button.

description.text:
This is a 6 axis stepper motor robot I built. You can download the bill of materials, instructions, arduino program and control software I wrote on github https://github.com/Chris-Annin/Annin-Robot-Project

here is a demo video of the robot:
https://youtu.be/XkAfb8alqnI

next gen
https://youtu.be/AeCLbhPHltw

comments.text: Your instruction set for this robotic arm is the most clear, comprehensive one that I have yet seen. While other designs may have more robust hardware none that I've encountered match the clarity of your software control. The interface is great. I'm learning python this quarter but once I've attained greater proficiency I'm eager to look at your source code in greater depth to see how you're communicating with the arduino clone. Based on other designs on this platform I thought that I'd have to use GRBL or Pronterface even though those were designed only for 3 axis control and would need modification.
comments.author: chuteroo

comments.text: Thank you. It seemed that GRBL was structured around 3 axis machines and I was looking to create something that resembled the controls of an industrial 6 axis robot that wouldn't require any coding from the user.  I rolled the program completely from scratch including my attempt at solving the kinamatics. its fairly basic in how it works.  I didn't choose python for any reason other than its a popular language that I had a little bit of familiarity with but I wanted to learn more about.  this is basically my first real project using arduinos or python.  the python program tracks motor position and motor steps, calculates destination and number of steps required to each of the 6 joints.  the program sends the arduino a string command that defines number of steps, speed (as a percentage of max capable speed) and acceleration/deceleration (as percentage of programmed speed / magnitude of movement).  When the arduino receives the movements there is an algorithm that determines frequency to skip steps within in the loop for the motors with shorter distances to travel so that all motors attempt to finish their move at approx same time.  This algorithm divides and splits up the steps in 3 segments - this could be refined further given more time to work with it but for now the motors mostly finish together.  The acceleration and deceleration basically manipulates the speed (time between steps) based on taking a percentage of the distance at the beginning and end of the move and then increasing or decreasing the pause time incrementally throughout that segment of the move. I'm not sure how GRBL algorithm "smooths" the steps but in my case i have most of the steppers at 1/4 steps with some basic timing algorithms.  Im not sure about about incorporating path planning software - I would need to be much further along in the kinamatics and control relative to stepper motors.  currently my biggest challenge is the kinamatics.  I didnt want to someone elses library as I wanted to figure it out for myself.  what I came up with works for the most part in its most basic form - you can jog the robot in XYZ and reorient the wrist but it does have some trouble correctly re-calculating the orientation of the wrist given a distance moved in XYZ, most of the time it works but in particular orientations it makes unexpected moves.  Im not a math wizard and barely made it through high school - the forward kinematics use basic DH parameters and the inverse uses geometric means given arm forward configuration and then rotation matrices and the inverse of J3 position matrix (basically decoupled J1-3 for position and J4-6 for orientation).  But this is just to jog to a destination position -the robot moves from point A to point B, there is not path control - (being able to traverse a straight line or calculated arc) being that its a single serial command for each new move to destination position.  it does happen to resemble a straight line movement as the axis work in parallel but not controlled.  I think my next step is to just finish up the drawings - instructions and release what I have for Gen2 so people can see / play with it.  Then I need to go back to school and or study kinematic packages or incorporate robot toolbox package and keep improving the program as I have time.  let me know if any other questions or if this answers what you wanted to know.
comments.author: chuteroo

comments.text: That's very helpful, thank you. I look forward to building my own when classes end. Good luck with the rest of the project!
comments.author: chris-annin

comments.text:
here is the latest
https://youtu.be/AeCLbhPHltw
comments.author: chris-annin

comments.text: Very cool man! I think you did a great job on your robotic arm. I also want to build a robotic arm. But, after watching your video. I see there is SO! much more to it than just printing parts & connecting motors. You obviously have an immense working knowledge of electronics & programming. Which is much greater than mine. So a build like this may be above my skill level. Which is why it is so impressive. Great Work! Also, I Really like your Home built CNC Machine. I am a Machinist, So I can appreciate the machine that you have built there as well.

comments.text: Thank you for the compliment. I don't think it would be above skill level for anyone to build it, the github project has all the instructions and software you can download. Im working on the next version though that's a bit larger and uses geared stepper motors and the build is a little simpler or professional I would say. I'm also working on the fwd and rev kinematic for Cartesian movement.  I'd wait a few months til I can put out the next design.  Thanks again.

I will take that time to build on my skills. I now have a Arduino Uno, that I hope to learn with. Thanks for sharing ur design's & for the work that you put into them. Take care

description.text:
This is a smaller spool in 2 pieces which screw together. It is intended for winding your smaller quantities of filament, leftovers, etc. I am finding it quite useful for my filament samples from MakerBox as well as winding small quantity leftovers.

This is a very, very quick remix of the "small spool" thing created by tamel55. It's an awesome and handy design, but when I tried to slice it in Simplify3D or Cura, the threads on the male side of the spool came out with lots of holes in between the threads, almost like the wall behind them was made of mesh.

So I simply dragged the model into Tinkercad, "sleeved" the inner surface to thicken it by about 1mm all around, and it sliced fine after that. All credit for the elegant & handy design goes to tamel55.

Bi-color print was not planned. I just ran out of blue & grabbed a box labelled "purple." I guess a light magenta passes for purple in China. LOL

Printer:

Monporice Maker Select i3 v2.1

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.25mm

Infill:

50% rectilinear (Simplify3D)

Notes:

Printed at 200C with 60C bed using Hatchbox standard PLA. 3 outer shells % 50% rectilinear infill, but I think when I print another, I will go 4 shells & lower the infill to 20-30%.

description.text:
I needed a shade from the sun for my Garmin Nuvi 1300. Customize your own. Be warned... after a couple of days in the hot car, it warped. It was printed in PETG filament. I may have to resort to sheet metal.

Customize this in OpenScad (free). Export to STL. Slice in your favorite slicer (Slic3r). Send g-code to printer.

I would print a partial test print with a zero visor length to make sure you dimensions are accurate. Be sure to flip (rotate on z axis). The top of the visor should be flat on the printer bed.

Full disclosure: I live in Georgia USA were the heat inside a car out in the sun can kill. My PETG visor can't hold up to the heat and it warps. I can generally get the warp flattened back out by putting it on a Pizza stone in the oven at about 200 deg. For me, I can only use my visor from October through March. It might work better in white, but that is a lot of glare on the windshield.

Makerfront i3Pro XL

These are expansion components to be used along with the Learning Resources Robot STEM Mouse in teaching coding to grades Preschool through 2nd Grade. These components such as the Baby Robot STEM Mouse are used as objects in mission challenges.

The Baby Robot STEM Mouse may be 3D printed with the bottom part as large block of cheese (yellow) then using z-axis pause and filament change, the baby mouse may be printed as white.

The Baby Robot STEM Mouse prototype .stl was not designed exactly to the contour of the Robot STEM Mouse. There are several different .stl files from experimenting that need some improvements.

While this prototype works for the purposes of objectives, a much better build would have been achieved with a 3D scanner. That would be phase 2 of this project or something someone with a scanner could complete.

A perfect contour of the Codey mother mouse on 4 sides of the Baby Mouse box would allow us to give students 2-dimensional challenges where they push the Baby Mouse box in one x-axis direction, back out, go around to a side, then push the Baby Mouse box in the y-axis direction.

This video was made before adding the Baby Robot STEM Mouse however it gives you an idea of how an activity progresses.

Baby Robot STEM Mouse

Help save Baby Robot STEM Mouse by programming Mommy Mouse to take baby home!

Overview & Background

Educators will get more ideas to expand their use of the Learning Resources Robot STEM Mouse. Create new mission challenges for Codey to get the baby mouse to home base.

Objectives

Students will practice designing the code necessary to push the baby mouse to the target location.

Audiences

Baby Robot STEM Mouse is geared towards K-G2.

Subjects

Computer Science

Skills Learned (Standards)

K-2-ETS1-2. Develop a simple sketch, drawing, or physical model to illustrate how the shape of an object helps it function as needed to solve a given problem.
K-2-ETS1-3. Analyze data from tests of two objects designed to solve the same problem to compare the strengths and weaknesses of how each performs.

Lesson/Activity

Duration:
Mission challenges can vary from 2 minutes to 30 minutes depending on how many different missions the educator wishes to give students.

Preparation:
Baby Robot STEM Mouse missions are challenges that educators can add on to the standard mission cards included with the Learning Resources Robot STEM Mouse. Educators can copy the original cards and add the Baby Robot STEM Mouse in there or make new maps.

The most basic example shown in the picture is to have the baby mouse placed at a location that has line-of-sight to the cheese then challenge the student to use Codey the mommy mouse to push baby mouse to the piece of cheese then back out and go around baby mouse to reach the cheese as well.

Right now the current .stl does not have the exact contour necessary to do 2-direction moves with the baby mouse. If we could 3D scan the mouse contour then we could probably create a more exact movement so that the Codey Mommy mouse could push in one direction then back out, go around to the side then push it from the side for 2 dimensional movement.

References

Learning Resources Robot STEM Mouse
https://www.learningresources.com/product/learning+essentials--8482-+stem+robot+mouse+coding+activity+set.do

Rubric & Assessment

Students should have plenty of cheering and clapping when completing the mission!

description.text:
Si vous souhaitez utiliser ces pièces, je vous recommande d'imprimer également ces autres pièces qui ont été créées par DAL:

  • Anti wooble supérieur adaptable : http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1240175
  • guidage haut tige filetée: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1260449
    Ainsi que celle-çi : http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1738716

Cette pièce remplace les anti-wobbles officiels de la Dagoma Discovery 200 qui étaient trop flexibles et avaient trop de jeu à mon goût:
Le plateau officiel n'étant pas plan, les 4 points du palpeurs ré-alignent un plan théorique d'impression... et cela se traduit par des va-et-vients sur l'axe Z pendant l'impression de chaque couche. Ces va-et-vient sont transmis en Z par ces anti-wobbles.

Ces nouvelles pièces sont plus rigides et permettent de régler l'écartement des fourches.

Configuration A: (voir les deux premières photos): l'écartement de la fourche est réglables (Vis M3 longueur 16 mm + écrou). Dans cette config, j'ai - dans un premier temps -placé des rondelles M8 entre ces anti-wooble et le chariot Z, et ai resserré l'écartement des fourches en laissant un jeu suffisant pour ne pas créer une friction trop grande.
Après plusieurs essais, j'ai constaté que l'usage des rondelles n'était finalement pas une bonne option car elles viennent parfois glisser horizontalement et donc frotter sur la tige Z en générant de la friction... je l'ai ai donc retirées et depuis ce n'est que du bonheur...

Configuration B (voir les deux dernières photos): ou alors ces mêmes trous peuvent servir à faire passer des serflex plastiques afin de plaquer les fourches contre le chariot X.

La configuration A me donne aujourd'hui entière satisfaction (moins de jeu, moins de wobble, moins de bruits).

Impression : couche "fin" de 0,1 mm, rempli 30%

for one of my 1/16 E-Revos Shocks the black Springs that I ordered
turned out to be shorter in length, so I had to adjust the spring
all the way down running out of thread on the shocks. so I decided
to design these spaces to address the issue with the spring at the
rear shocks to eliminate the droup in the rear. If you decide to
download this parts you will need to do some sanding especially
where i Use the Dremel inside one of the spacer as you see in
one of the photos to get rid of some excess off of the spacer
to make it easier to slide that part onto the shocks themselves
and in the photos also i show you how to remove the shocks and
install the spacers on to the shocks themselves you should get
the idea on how that is done so enjoy this part.

This was a summer project to create a one piece 3d printed electric longboard. Is your printer big enough? For those that can't print it all in one go, I'll upload files later of the board split in thirds. It is solid Ultem 1010 and engineered to hold 280 lbs. Still a work in progress though. The space on the bottom houses 2 x 4s Lipo batteries, 120a esc, and a 2.4ghz receiver. The bottom of the board is covered by a 3/16" aluminum plate that is fastened by 4xM4 bolts.

Printed on a Fortus 900mc

Print Time: 6 days

Used http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:545345 for the large spur pulley on the wheel. Printed out of Ultem 9085. Works really well.

Added deck split into 3 parts

UPDATED 9/12/16
Files for electric drive components coming shortly. Decided not to weld components to trucks. Instead I used set screws to bolt the mount on the truck. Lots of loctite needs to be used! Videos under How I Designed This section!

description.text:
This is a functional equivalent to the injection molded X-Axis Carriage mount on the Aurora A3 printer with some improvements. It should mount and function exactly the same as the original part. I purchased this 3D Printer early 2016, so older/newer models may be slightly different.

I beefed up the back plate as well as mounting holes for the linear bearings. I tried to eliminate any slop in the original design as well as make the whole structure stronger.

The parts are designed with a .25mm tollerance, so they will fit together very snugly and may require a little sanding/filing on the corners to square them up. I recommend printing this on a slower speed to improve accuracy and help with assembly.

Recat also has a resigned variant of the same carriage: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1148159

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

JG Aurora A3 Prusa I3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2mm or .1mm

Infill:

15% or more

Notes:

Highly recommend printing this slower than normal so you get good clean corners and screw holes.


I also suggest infill more than 15% for added strength and top/bottom sides of 1.2mm or more.

comments.text:
Thanks!
I saw your make. It printed beautifully!
comments.author: varind

comments.text: I went to print this in ABS+ tonight and yay, warping finally reared its ugly head. It wasn't even bad but it was enough to irritate me enough to stop the print. Is it okay to print parts for the printer in PLA or will it result in quality issues with parts and longevity issues too? The parts that came with the printer look to be PLA too but I'm unsure. Just wanted another opinion before I use up some of my precious PLA spool haha
comments.author: Dinster

comments.text:
The X-Carriage part that came with the printer are injection molded plastic - probably ABS, as they feel a lot like Legos (also ABS).
You can try printing it with a raft or brim to keep it from warping with ABS.
I do believe PLA will be fine - providing you don't leave your printer out in the rain or direct sunlight for a few weeks :)
PLA is touted as 'bio-degradable', but they're talking decades in a compost pile. Whereas ABS would take centuries.
It starts getting soft around 50c and is a bit brittle at room temp, but the X-Carriage does not get a lot of abuse nor is it very close to the hot-end. The cooling fan ducts are a lot closer and they do tend to warp a bit, but I've never had one de-laminate in PLA.
All the other printed parts on the A3 are PLA as far as I can tell.
I suggest printing it with at least 1.2mm top/bottom/sides and infill of 20% or more (but not 100% infill)
If your still not sure, try PETG. Its as strong, or stronger than ABS, not as toxic fumes, more flexible than PLA and not nearly as brittle. Plus it has a higher softening temp that PLA. But I've never tried it on Blue Tape.
comments.author: Dinster

comments.text: I'm curious as to why you do not recommend 100% infill for this?
comments.author: DaHai8

comments.text:
Depending on the material used, shrinkage can be a big problem when printing with 100% infill. Also heating and cooling of the part can cause more warping or cracking when its solid as there is no internal 'give' .
The strength gained 100% is only incremental over lower percentages, like 80% or less. And this part doesn't really get stressed as much as compared to the X-Axis Stepper motor and idler mounts.
There's the added weight to factor in as well for a constantly moving part. Every little bit helps.
Just my opinions and experiences. YMMV. :)
